III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility runs an event called Quest twice a year. The children
go out in the woods for a week. They explore the wilderness. On
these explorations they have to defecate in the woods and cannot
shower for the entirety of the week. They sleep in tents and hike
with heavy backpacks.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via telephone on
2/19/2025. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A reported
concerns about quest. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A has
not been on quest at the facility however was informed by other
youth at the facility about quest. Foster Care Worker reached out
to Case Manager and learned more information about quest.
Foster Care Worker learned from Case Manager quest is run by
trained staff where youth go on a camping trip for educational
purposes and stay in cabins with restrooms and showers.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Youth A reported she has not attended a quest trip at
the facility yet as she arrived in the fall after quest occurred.
Youth A reported she was informed by other youth, unable to
recall who, that during quest youth are not able to shower for one
week. Youth A reported she was told during quest youth use the
bathroom in the woods and carry a backpack that weighs “multiple
pounds” for “miles and miles”. Youth A reported she was told
youth must sleep in a tent in the woods where there are animals.
Youth A reported she “is not doing that”. Youth A reported she
heard about quest from more than one youth at the facility
however did not remember who.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Youth B reported she attended quest in September
2024. Youth B reported over a four-day period youth and staff
hiked ten miles, with typically walking about three miles a day.
Youth B reported two of the nights were spent sleeping in tents
and two nights sleeping in cabins. Youth B reported she did not
shower for four days while on the trip. Youth B reported youth
carry backpacks that “weigh a lot”. Youth B reported clothing,
hygiene products, food, cooking supplies, and parts of the tent are
carried in the backpacks. Youth B reported she did not know how
much her backpack weighed. Youth B reported while on the hiking
trip, if youth or staff need to use the bathroom, youth are provided
toilet paper to go to the bathroom in the woods. Youth B reported
there are no outhouses along the trail.
2

Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Youth C reported she has attended three quests while
at the facility. Youth C reported youth and staff hike with “big
backpacks”, sleep outside in tents, and use the bathroom
outdoors. Youth C reported quest is five days/four nights with two
nights sleeping in tents and two nights where youth sleep in
cabins. Youth C reported the cabins have showers and
bathrooms. Youth C reported youth can shower when staying in
the cabins. Youth C reported youth and staff hike about three to
four miles a day. Youth C reported youth are prepared for quest
prior to going as youth learn how to pack a hiking bag. Youth C
reported backpacks contain food, water, clothing, sleeping bag,
and the tent.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Administrator 1 reported the facility does do “quest”
twice a year at the facility which consists of a camping trip Monday
through Friday. Administrator 1 reported youth stay two nights in
tents and two nights in cabins with electricity. Administrator 1
reported the youth do learn about backpacking prior to “quest” to
prepare them for the event. Youth do backpack through the
woods with a backpack and use the bathroom outdoors when
youth are on the trail for the hike if they need to use the bathroom.
The cabins have bathrooms and showers for the youth to use
while the youth are staying in the cabins for that portion of the
week.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Administrator 2 reported the facility does do “quest”
twice a year at the facility. There is a quest in the spring and a
quest in the fall. Administrator 2 reported quest are camping
experiences to give the youth the camping experience and teach
youth about camping and backpacking.
Administrator 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Administrator 3 reported there are two formats that
occur for quest. One of the quest trips is an outdoor adventure
where youth learn to hike and backpack in the woods and the
second form of quest is a “family vacation” style where youth stay
in cabins and attend activities where youth go to Craig’s Cruzers
and ride go carts and go to Lewis Farms. Administrator 3 reported
prior to the facility scheduling the outdoor quest, staff assess the
current youth to determine the format and schedule for quest. For
the outdoor quest, the facility prepare youth for the hiking and
backpacking trip by educating youth about recreational
backpacking and how to set up a tent and back a backpack.
3

Administrator 3 reported during the outdoor quest, youth hike two
to six miles a day with highly qualified staff. Youth carry
backpacks that are fitted and designed based on the youth’s age
and size. Youth learn to “toilet train” prior to going on the hiking
trip which youth learn how to use the bathroom outdoors on the
trail. Administrator 3 reported there are not bathrooms along the
trail so both youth and staff do go to the bathroom outdoors.
Administrator 3 reported there are outhouses to use at certain
points along the trail. Administrator 3 reported youth and staff
sleep in tents and there are staff up at night to provide supervision
throughout the night. Administrator 3 reported the outdoor hiking
trip is a three day/ two-night trip.
Experiential Program Manager was interviewed face-to-face
at the facility on 2/24/2025. Experiential Program Manager
reported the facility holds two experiential trips a year. One event
is held in the spring where youth stay in cabins at Grace and do
day hikes. The second event is held in the fall where youth are
gone for five days/ four nights for a backpack trip. Experiential
Program Manager reported the fall trip has “morphed” over the
years and now consists of two nights spent camping in tents and
hiking and the other two nights staying in cabins with electricity
and showers. Experiential Program Manager reported during the
hike, youth carry backpacks containing clothing, food, sleeping
bags, and take turns carrying pieces of the tent. Experiential
Program Manager reported youth do use the bathroom in the
woods while hiking if they need to use the restroom. Youth are
prepared prior to the trip to learn about “toilet training” in the
woods as well as youth are taught to set up tents, how to cook
when on backpacking trips, and how to pack a backpack for
hiking. Experiential Program Manager reported youth are
prepared “a lot” prior to leaving for the hiking trip. Experiential
Program Manager reported if there are outhouses along the trail,
youth are able to use the outhouses. While the youth are tent
camping for two nights, there are not showers, however at the
cabins there are bathrooms and showers. Experiential Program
Manager reported therapeutically the experiential trips are very
helpful for youth. Experiential Program Manager reported she is
also a trained therapist and while on the experiential trips she
conducts sessions with youth and finds youth tend to open up
more.
Documents Reviewed:
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures Adventure Based Experiential Learning
Program: Quest is a wilderness camping program—on-
4

campus experiential programming and off-campus wilderness
experience. It addresses the following areas: Education:
Through planned outdoor experiences-character principles
are taught and basic outdoor skills are covered; Personal
Development: It provides a context within which individuals
can grow physically, mentally, socially and spiritually.
Individuals can find out more about themselves, their
developmental needs, and how they relate to the larger,
natural world around them; Psychological: What occurs
during Quest is reality-based. The experiences the individual
has in outdoor programming are immediate, pertinent and
relevant to their current situation; Social: The individual can
learn about themselves and their relationship or impact on
others. It assists the individual in identifying patterns of
behavior; Ecological: It teaches the individual about the out-
of-doors and the complex relationship that links things
together.
• Eagle Village Program Statement: Abuse/Neglect
Programming includes but is not limited to: Experiential
programming, including a wilderness component,
Recreational therapy, and individual/family experiential
interventions.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as the facility indicates in the
program statement youth will have programming including
experiential programing with a wilderness component, recreational
therapy, and experiential interventions. Youth are prepared for
the quest experiential activities prior to quest and are guided by
trained staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4160 Emergency Restraint
Section The use of emergency restraint as a lifesaving response for a
Description youth will be limited to:
(a) An emergency response to protect the youth or others from
an unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places the
youth or others at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth are restrained for refusing to go on Quest.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via telephone on
2/19/2025. Foster Care Worker reported she did not know of any
specific information of any specific youth being restrained for
refusing to attend quest.
5

Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Youth A reported she has never attended quest.
Youth A reported she was informed about quest by other youth at
the facility. Youth A reported she was told by other youth at the
facility if youth refuse to attend quest, then the youth is restrained.
Youth A reported she did not remember which youth told her
youth are restrained if youth refuse to attend quest. Youth A did
not remember when she was told by other youth about quest.
Youth A reported she did not know when the facility plans to have
the next quest.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Youth B reported she attended quest in September
2024. Youth B reported youth have tried to refuse to attend quest
however youth are not allowed to refuse. Youth B reported she
did not know what happens if youth refuse, youth just end up
going. Youth B reported she did not see any youth get restrained
in September for refusing to go on quest.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Youth C reported she has been on three quests at the
facility. Youth C reported one youth was escorted away from the
water on quest in September as the youth was in the water and
was not supposed to be and was not following staff direction.
Youth C reported she was not aware of any youth being restrained
for refusing to attend quest.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Administrator 1 reported youth are not restrained if
they refuse to attend quest.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Administrator 2 reported youth are not restrained if
they refuse to attend quest.
Administrator 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
2/24/2025. Administrator 3 reported the same protocol regarding
restraints are followed while at quest. Administrator 3 reported
youth are not restrained for refusing to attend quest.
Administrator 3 reported if a youth refuses to go on quest or
refuses to hike on quest, staff talk to the youth to understand why
the youth does not want to go or hike and work through the
youth’s refusal with providing assurance and preparing the youth
for what to expect at quest.
6

Experiential Program Manager was interviewed face-to-face
at the facility on 2/24/2025. Experiential Program Manager
reported no knowledge of any youth being restrained due to
refusing to attend quest in the thirteen years Experiential Program
Manager has been employed at the facility.
Documents Reviewed:
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures Therapeutic Holds: When staff have attempted
to help the youth de-escalate without the success of the
youth returning to a safe and regulated state; the use of a
Therapeutic Hold may become necessary to keep the youth
safe. The only approved therapeutic hold techniques are the
methods and techniques taught in the required Aegis course
and should only be used when a resident is a serious threat
of safety or violence to self or others and/or after all verbal
de-escalation and behavior support techniques have been
exhausted. Therapeutic holds must not be used for
punishment, discipline, or retaliation.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per interviews with staff and
youth, there were no reported incidents where youth were
restrained from refusing to attend quest.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
